text: At the beginning of April, Carbon Black Threat Research began analyzing a malware variant commonly referred to as Red Leaves, which appears to have code reuse from the PlugX family.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: During the last month, this malware family has been referenced in several security blogs and government alerts.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: Carbon Black is publicly providing this technical write up to assist customers, other organizations, and researchers continuing to investigate incidents related to this malware family.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: Along with this report, Carbon Black is providing product specific queries, rules and scripts aimed at assisting in the detection and analysis of this malware family in the Carbon Black User Exchange.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The overall process of how the malware’s components are created on an infected system and the different points where the suite of Carbon Black products could detect the different stages of the malware are outlined in that User Exchange post.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: This malware family has been observed in the wild since at least June 2016.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The malware uses a technique called DLL side loading, which is common with the PlugX family.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: DLL sideloading works by using a legitimate or benign executable file to load a modified DLL.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: This DLL is responsible for loading and executing an encoded or encrypted malicious data file.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The ultimate payload for this sample is a shellcode loader, which injects the Red Leaves implant, via process hollowing, into a hard coded process.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The metadata for the initial dropper file that was analyzed is listed in the information below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The initial stage of the sample analyzed has little functionality outside of dropping or creating the malicious second stage files on the infected system.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: PlugX has in the past been documented as being delivered via a self extracting (SFX) Rar executable, which acts as the first stage dropper.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: Once the files have been created on disk, the dropper will execute the Obedience.exe file, starting the overall process.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: A brief overview of the entire process is outlined in the below two figures and the accompanying table.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The first stage dropper will push several hard-coded values to a function, which is responsible for decoding the three embedded files.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: These files comprise the second stage of the overall malware setup.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The image below displays these values being pushed (highlighted in red) as well as being labeled for clarity.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The pushed values in the above image (file offsets and sizes), are passed to a function responsible for decoding and writing the files to disk, along with the hard coded file names.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The embedded files are decoded by the function displayed in the image below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The function will decode the first half of the file with one set of XOR keys (these instructions are highlighted in red), and the second half of the function with a different set of XOR keys (these instructions are highlighted in yellow).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The XOR key sets are derived from a 16 byte ASCII string immediately preceding the encoded data, in which every other byte is used to XOR each byte of encoded data.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The first eight bytes are used for the first half of the file and the last 8 bytes for the second half of the file.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: To clarify this process, the data in the table below represents one of the encoded embedded files.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The first 16 bytes (which are in bold) are the ASCII string, from which the key sets are derived.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The first half of the file is decoded by XORing each byte of encoded data with each byte which is designated in red below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The second half is of the file is then decoded in the same manner using the each byte, in blue, from the second half of the overall string.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The same result can be obtained by XORing each byte of the 4 byte key and then using the result to XOR each byte of encoded data, which in this specific scenario is 0x1B and clearly visible from the null areas of an executable file.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The file labeled as embed_1 is a legitimate and validly signed executable (typically used in conjunction with different CD software applications), and in this sample will be created as the hard coded name obedience.exe (it should be noted that the file name could easily be changed in other variants).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The file labeled as embed_2 is a slightly modified file that will be named StarBurn.dll.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The final file labeled as embed_3 is an encoded file that when decoded and executed will inject the Red Leaves implant into the memory of a target process.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: All of these files will be be created in the current user’s Temp folder (ex. C:Users[account]AppDataLocalTemp).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The first stage dropper is also responsible for installing the persistence mechanism for the malware, as a shortcut named persuasion.lnk in the current user’s startup folder.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The shortcut or link file will point to the target file obedience.exe and will execute that file when the user logs into the system.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: Once the benign file obedience.exe has been executed it loads several libraries, one of which is StarBurn.dll.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The below image displays the Import table from Obedience showing where the malicious GetVersion function is imported.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The StarBurn.dll is side loaded, which is a fairly common tactic often associated with the PlugX family.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: Once the GetVersion function from StarBurn.dll is imported it will execute and look for the hard coded filename handkerchief.dat in the directory where StarBurn.dll is located.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The image below highlights these actions.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The handkerchief.dat file’s data is then read into memory.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The pseudo-code in the image below highlights the the next steps in the process (variables were renamed for clarity).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The StarBurn.dll function will make the address space where the handkerchief.dat data was read into memory read, write and executable (which is highlighted in the first red box).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The function will then decode the data in the same manner in which the previous embedded files were decoded, where a 16 byte ASCII string is used to derive 2 XOR key sets, which are then used to decode the first and second half of the files.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The StarBurn.dll function will then create a thread with the starting address of the decoded data, is highlighted in the second red box.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The decoded data is shellcode with an additional embedded payload.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The table below is a small excerpt of the decoded shellcode, which will load the Red Leaves implant into memory.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The shellcode will load several common libraries which will be used to inject the Red Leaves payload into memory.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The shellcode decodes (using a single byte XOR of 0x53) a portion of the implant’s configuration block, where the processname is stored that will be injected into via process hollowing.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The image below shows the code responsible for configuration decoding, highlighted in red.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The shellcode loader will then create a process in suspended state, in this case the target process was Iexplore.exe.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The image below, which has been commented for clarity, displays where the shellcode creates the suspended thread.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The Red Leaves payload will then be written to that process’ memory location and the thread is then resumed allowing the Red Leaves implant to impersonate Internet Explorer and communicate with the pre-configure C2s.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: As other research reports have pointed the embedded Red Leaves implant has the MZ and PE ASCII characters from the DOS and PE headers overwritten with the values 0xFF, which are highlighted in red in the table below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: Once the Red Leaves malware is running the program will initially decode its configuration block, which is encoded using a single byte XOR (in this example the 0x53).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: This functionality is highlighted in the image below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The configuration block is 0x940 bytes in length and contains several different options related to how the malware will install itself as well as where and how it will communicate with the hard coded C2s.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The configuration block itself is a list of null terminated strings and binary values, which correspond to hard coded values.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The configuration block is detailed in the table below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The Value section are the values present in the sample that was analyzed.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: After the configuration data has been decoded the malware will go into the main communication thread creation function, which is responsible for initiating the communications to the embedded C2s.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The connection mode value is evaluated and the malware will used the appropriate functions to either use a custom protocol or standard APIs to communicate with the C2s.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The value in this sample is 4 which will then attempt to resolve the different C2s iterating through the ports 443, 53, 80, and 995 (in that specific order).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: Once a connection has been established the malware will communicate with the C2 utilizing the RC4 algorithm with the key “Lucky123”.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The malware uses a series of command Identifiers, which are parsed, and then the program will pass control to the appropriate functions to carry out commands and return the responses or data back to the C2.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The jump table responsible for evaluating commands is displayed in the image below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The communication protocol has been well documented in other research papers, which can be reviewed for further information.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Dissects Red Leaves Malware, Which Leverages DLL Side Loading - VMware Security Blog - VMware.html

text: The malware itself has the following capabilities, which allow the malware to be used as an efficient Remote Access Tool (RAT).

text: Since around October 2016, JPCERT/CC has been confirming emails that are sent to Japanese organisations with a ZIP file attachment containing executable files.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The targeted emails, which impersonate existing persons, are sent from free email address services available in Japan.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Also, the executable files’ icons are disguised as Word documents.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: When the recipient executes the file, the machine is infected with malware called ChChes.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: This blog article will introduce characteristics of ChChes, including its communication.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: While some ZIP files attached to the targeted emails in this campaign contain executable files only, in some cases they also contain dummy Word documents.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Below is the example of the latter case.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: In the above example, two files with similar names are listed: a dummy Word document and an executable file whose icon is disguised as a Word document.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: By running this executable file, the machine will be infected with ChChes.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: JPCERT/CC has confirmed the executable files that have signatures of a specific code signing certificate.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The dummy Word document is harmless, and its contents are existing online articles related to the file name “Why Donald Trump won”.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
The details of the code signing certificate is described in Appendix A.
ChChes is a type of malware that communicates with specific sites using HTTP to receive commands and modules.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: There are only few functions that ChChes can execute by itself.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: This means it expands its functions by receiving modules from C&C servers and loading them on the memory.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The following is an example of HTTP GET request that ChChes sends.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Sometimes, HEAD method is used instead of GET.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: As you can see, the path for HTTP request takes /[random string].htm, however, the value for the Cookie field is not random but encrypted strings corresponding to actual data used in the communication with C&C servers.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The value can be decrypted using the below Python script.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The following is the flow of communication after the machine is infected.

text: The value in the Cookie field of the HTTP request that ChChes first sends (Request 1) contains encrypted data starting with ‘A’.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The following is an example of data sent.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text:
The details are specified in Appendix B.
As a response to Request 1, ChChes receives strings of an ID identifying the infected machine from C&C servers (Response 1).
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The ID is contained in the Set-Cookie field as shown below.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Next, ChChes sends an HTTP request to receive modules and commands (Request 2).

text: At this point, the following data starting with ‘B’ is encrypted and contained in the Cookie field.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: As a response to Request 2, encrypted modules and commands (Response 2) are sent from C&C servers.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: The following shows an example of received modules and commands after decryption.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Commands are sent either together with modules as a single data (as above), or by itself.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Afterwards, execution results of the received command are sent to C&C servers, and it returns to the process to receive modules and commands.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: This way, by repeatedly receiving commands from C&C servers, the infected machines will be controlled remotely.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: JPCERT/CC’s research has confirmed modules with the following functions, which are thought to be the bot function of ChChes.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: Especially, it was confirmed that the module that encrypts the communication with AES is received in a relatively early stage after the infection.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: With this feature, communication with C&C servers after this point will be encrypted in AES on top of the existing encryption method.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: ChChes is a relatively new kind of malware which has been seen since around October 2016.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: As this may be continually used for targeted attacks, JPCERT/CC will keep an eye on ChChes and attack activities using the malware.
source: ChChes – Malware that Communicates with C&C Servers Using Cookie Headers - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html

text: In April 2017, a previously unknown group calling itself IntrusionTruth began releasing blog posts detailing individuals believed to be associated with major Chinese intrusion campaigns.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: Although the group’s exact motives remain unclear, its initial tranche of information exposed individuals connected to long-running GOTHIC PANDA (APT3) operations, culminating in a connection to the Chinese firm Boyusec (博御信息) and, ultimately, Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS) entities in Guangzhou.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: Recently, in July and August 2018, IntrusionTruth has returned with new reporting regarding actors with ties to historic STONE PANDA (APT10) activity and has ultimately associated them with the MSS Tianjin Bureau (天津市国家安全局).
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: Though CrowdStrike® Falcon Intelligence™ is currently unable to confirm all of the details provided in these most recent posts with a high degree of confidence, several key pieces of information can be verified.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: More details that may further illuminate these findings and provide a higher confidence in connecting STONE PANDA to the MSS Tianjin Bureau are likely to emerge.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: Throughout May 2017, using a variety of historical information and open-source intelligence (OSINT), IntrusionTruth released several blog posts identifying several individuals connected to Boyusec.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: Though CrowdStrike’s Threat Intelligence team had suspected GOTHIC PANDA was an MSS contractor for several years, the IntrusionTruth posts and subsequent research by RecordedFuture into MSS ties to the China Information Technology Evaluation Center (CNITSEC/中国信息安全测评中心) corroborated additional details from various sources and provided a higher degree of confidence.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: Confidence in these findings was further boosted when the U.S. Department of Justice named Boyusec and several of the described individuals in an indictment, and detailed GOTHIC PANDA tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) in detail.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: CrowdStrike Falcon® Intelligence was able to independently verify the majority of this information and concluded that not only is CNITSEC associated with the MSS, but its former director WU Shizhong (吴世忠) was simultaneously dual-hatted as the director of the MSS Technology/13th Bureau (国家安全部科技局局长)1 2 3, implying that the MSS plays a crucial role in China’s code review of foreign products and is now able to cherry pick high-value vulnerabilities from its own capable domestic bug hunting teams.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: CNITSEC’s role in code review for foreign entities has led to its access to Microsoft’s source code dating back to 2003 and the use by KRYPTONITE PANDA of a high-value vulnerability (CVE-2018-0802), discovered by Chinese firm Qihoo 360, a month before it was publicly revealed.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: WU Shizhong Presenting on the “Digital Silk Road” at the Second Wuzhen World Internet Conference in 2015
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: As research into the IntrusionTruth leads on STONE PANDA continues, Falcon Intelligence has already observed some consistencies with known MSS operations.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text:
Many of the personal details for GAO were scrubbed shortly after IntrusionTruth’s post introducing him went live, including his
Tencent QQ account.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: The blog connects him to the moniker fisherxp via an initial spear-phishing campaign from 2010 previously attributed to STONE PANDA.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: Multiple sites with profile pictures appear to show the owner of the fisherxp accounts, though this has yet to be independently confirmed as GAO.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: Fisherxp’s QQ shows his alternate username as 肥猪 or “big porker”.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: IntrusionTruth later links GAO to several documented Uber rides to the MSS Tianjin Bureau’s office address where both his first name, Qiang/强, and 猪 are used by the app to identify him and tie him to the QQ number 420192.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: CrowdStrike cannot confirm the validity of these Uber receipts at this time.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: However, fisherxp’s account on popular Chinese technology forum 51CTO is still active and shows that he has downloaded not only the open-source DarkComet RAT and numerous password cracking tools, but more importantly, several favorite tools used by a plethora of known Chinese cyber adversaries including Gh0st RAT 3.6, zxarps (an ARP-spoofing tool by legacy hacker LZX), and lcx.exe (a port-forwarding tool by legacy hacker LCX)4.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: ZHANG was originally introduced by IntrusionTruth as a reciprocal follower of fisherxp’s Twitter account via his own @baobeilong account.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text:
Baobeilong (宝贝龙/”Baby Dragon”) also maintained a GitHub account that had forked both the Quasar
and Trochilus RATs, two open-source tools historically used by STONE PANDA, but the account has since been scrubbed.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: This information was verified by CrowdStrike before being removed completely.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: Falcon Intelligence recently independently conducted detailed analysis of the RedLeaves malware used to target numerous Japanese defense groups and found it was directly sourced from Trochilus code, but it has undergone several evolutions and contains prefixes suggesting it could also be used to target Russia and the DPRK.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: There is no conclusive evidence at this time that RedLeaves is solely attributed to STONE PANDA.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: Baobeilong did maintain a Flickr account with numerous pictures that proved key in identifying his location later, similar to how cpyy’s photos helped identify his affiliation to the People’s Liberation Army (PLA) in CrowdStrike’s PUTTER PANDA report.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: IntrusionTruth then drew connections from baobeilong’s other online accounts to registrant details for xiaohong[.]org, which dated back to 2007 and revealed ZHANG’s full name—ZHANG Shilong.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text:
From there, a trail of overlapping registrant details reveals ZHANG’s hanzi characters for his name (张世龙), likely one of his personal home addresses, potential work addresses and several email addresses:
Specifically tracing registrant details from atreexp → robin4700 → eshilong shows that ZHANG was active registering sites as recently as June 5, 2018, including a personal blog where his picture and name features prominently along with several technology-related blog posts.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text:
A picture from baobeilong’s Flickr account shows a fire at the Tianjin Medical Center 120
The original blog post on GAO lists his contact information in recruitment postings for two separate companies, one of which is Laoying Baichen Instruments (characters unknown at the time of this writing).
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: No records could be found for such a firm, however, IntrusionTruth lists the address associated with it as Room 1102, Guanfu Mansion, 46 Xinkai Road, Hedong District, Tianjin (天津市河东区新开路46号冠福大厦1102).
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: During the course of investigating Laoying and the Guanfu mansion, Falcon Intelligence noticed that the Guanfu Mansion is also the registered address of a firm called Tianjin Henglide Technology Co., Ltd. (恒利德天津科技有限公司), which is listed as one of only a few “review centers” certified by CNITSEC in Tianjin5.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: Laoying and Henglide are listed as being on different floors, however having a CNITSEC review center in the same building is noteworthy given CNITSEC’s connection to MSS and previous linkage to Boyusec/GOTHIC PANDA.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: Zhang is believed to have taken the photo of the fire from the Wanchan Meizhuan Mansion.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: This is relatively close to both the Yuyang Complex (one of Zhang’s listed registrant addresses) and the Guanfu Mansion, Laoying Baichen’s listed address.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: The other firm GAO appears to have been recruiting for is Huaying Haitai (天津华盈海泰科技发展有限公司).
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: As the IntrusionTruth blog post mentions, it is a registered firm with two listed representatives, Fang Ting (方亭) and Sun Lei (孙杰), and a listed address of 1906 Fuyu Mansion (天津市河西区解放南路中段西侧富裕大厦1-1906).
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: Searches for more information on Huaying Haitai turned up two interesting government documents.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: One is a recruitment Excel sheet detailing recent graduates, their majors and their new employers and addresses.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: Huaying Haitai is listed as having hired a recently graduated female student from Nankai University in 2013 who majored in Japanese.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: This is interesting considering STONE PANDA’s extensive targeting of Japanese defense firms after this time period, but it is by no means conclusive evidence that the firm is connected to STONE PANDA.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: The second government document lists Huaying Haitai as the co-organizer of a Network Security Attack and Defense competition with the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology’s (MIIT) national training entity, NSACE6.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: It was open for all students of Henan Province.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: NSACE appears to be a national education body that teaches network information security, including offensive activity7.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: This information is particularly interesting given Boyusec’s previous work at CNITSEC’s Guangdong subsidiary setting up a joint active defense lab8.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: It suggests that these technology firms act as both shell companies and recruitment grounds for potential MSS use in cyber operations.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: The most recent IntrusionTruth post assesses that GAO’s Uber rides frequently took him from Huaying’s address at the Fuyu Mansion to 85 Zhujiang Road (珠江道85号).
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: When observed closely, the compound is a striking one complete with towers, a fenced perimeter with surveillance cameras, guarded entrances, and a building with a significant number of satellite dishes.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: There are no markers on the building and no government listed address; however, it is apparently difficult for locals to determine where the Tianjin Bureau’s location is as well.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: There are several Baidu questions asking what transportation routes are best to get to that specific address.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: Three separate ones specifically mention the 85 Zhujiang Road address as the headquarters for the MSS’s Tianjin Bureau and the difficulty in finding its location9 10 11.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: As with most cyber-enabled operations, satellite arrays are often indicative of installations with significant signals intelligence (SIGINT) capabilities.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: The Tianjin Bureau appears to have the potential for such capabilities, housing several large arrays that appear to have existed since at least January 2004.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text:
Barely visible satellite dishes from the street view of 85 Zhujiang Road outside the compound
There are still significant intelligence gaps that prevent Falcon Intelligence from making an assessment about STONE PANDA’s potential connections to the MSS Tianjin Bureau with a high degree of confidence.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: However, additional information is likely to materialize either directly from IntrusionTruth or from other firms in the infosec community who are undoubtedly looking at this material as well and may have unique insight of their own.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: Ultimately, IntrusionTruth’s prior releases on GOTHIC PANDA proved accurate and led to a U.S. Department of Justice indictment resulting in the dismantling of Boyusec.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: From their latest post, which contains GAO’s Uber receipts, it is clear the group’s information likely goes beyond merely available OSINT data.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: It cannot be ignored that there are striking similarities between the entities associated with GOTHIC PANDA and the actors and firms mentioned in the blogs about STONE PANDA.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: In addition, FalconIntelligence notes that following the late 2015 Sino-U.S. brief cyber detente, much of the responsibility for western cyber intrusion operations was handed to the MSS as the PLA underwent an extensive reform that is still currently underway, and which is consolidating its military cyber forces under the Strategic Support Force.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: Though the detente saw an initial drop in Chinese intrusion activity, it has steadily been increasing over the past several years, with a majority of the intrusions into western firms being conducted by suspected contractors.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: These adversaries are tracked by CrowdStrike as GOTHIC PANDA, STONE PANDA, WICKED PANDA, JUDGMENT PANDA, and KRYPTONITE PANDA.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: Many of these adversaries have begun targeting supply chain and upstream providers to establish a potential platform for future operations and enable the collection of larger sets of data.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: While the APT1, PUTTER PANDA, and Operation CameraShy reports all exposed PLA units at a time when Chinese military hacking against western firms was rampant, the attention has now swung toward identifying MSS contractors.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: The exposure of STONE PANDA as an MSS contractor would be another blow to China’s current cyber operations given STONE PANDA’s prolific targeting of a variety of sectors, and may prompt an additional U.S. investigation at a tenuous time for Sino-U.S. relations during an ongoing trade war.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: However, it is important to note that such public revelations often force these actors to cease operations, improve their operational security (OPSEC), and then return stronger than before.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: As such, CrowdStrike Falcon® Intelligence assesses that although Boyusec may have shuttered, elements of GOTHIC PANDA are likely to still be active.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: The same is likely to be true for STONE PANDA following a period of silence.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: The activities of STONE PANDA impact entities in the Aerospace & Defense, Government,  Healthcare, Technology,  Telecommunications Services of several nations.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: For more information on how to incorporate intelligence on threat actors like STONE PANDA into your security strategy, please visit the Falcon Intelligence product page.
source: Two Birds, One STONE PANDA.html

text: APT10 (MenuPass Group) is a Chinese cyber espionage group that FireEye has tracked since 2009.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: They have historically targeted construction and engineering, aerospace, and telecom firms, and governments in the United States, Europe, and Japan.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: We believe that the targeting of these industries has been in support of Chinese national security goals, including acquiring valuable military and intelligence information as well as the theft of confidential business data to support Chinese corporations.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: PwC and BAE recently issued a joint blog detailing extensive APT10 activity.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: In June 2016, FireEye iSIGHT intelligence first reported that APT10 expanded their operations.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: The group was initially detected targeting a Japanese university, and more widespread targeting in Japan was subsequently uncovered.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text:
Further collaboration between FireEye as a Service (FaaS), Mandiant and FireEye iSIGHT intelligence uncovered additional victims worldwide, a new suite of tools and novel techniques.
Leveraging its global footprint, FireEye has detected APT10 activity across six continents in 2016 and 2017.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: APT10 has targeted or compromised manufacturing companies in India, Japan and Northern Europe; a mining company in South America; and multiple IT service providers worldwide.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: We believe these companies are a mix of final targets and organizations that could provide a foothold in a final target.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: APT10 unveiled new tools in its 2016/2017 activity.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: In addition to the continued use of SOGU, the current wave of intrusions has involved new tools we believe are unique to APT10. HAYMAKER and SNUGRIDE have been used as first stage backdoors, while BUGJUICE and a customized version of the open source QUASARRAT have been used as second stage backdoors.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: These new pieces of malware show that APT10 is devoting resources to capability development and innovation.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: This recent APT10 activity has included both traditional spear phishing and access to victim’s networks through service providers.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: (For more information on infection via service providers see M-Trends 2016).
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: APT10 spear phishes have been relatively unsophisticated, leveraging .lnk files within archives, files with double extensions (e.g. “[Redacted]_Group_Meeting_Document_20170222_doc_.exe) and in some cases simply identically named decoy documents and malicious launchers within the same archive.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: In addition to the spear phishes, FireEye ISIGHT Intelligence has observed APT10 accessing victims through global service providers.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: Service providers have significant access to customer networks, enabling an attacker who had compromised a service provider to move laterally into the network of the service provider’s customer.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: In addition, web traffic between a service provider’s customer and a service provider is likely to be viewed as benign by network defenders at the customer, allowing the attacker to exfiltrate data stealthily.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: A notable instance of this observed by FireEye involved a SOGU backdoor that was set to communicate with its C2 through a server belonging to the victim’s service provider.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text:
APT10 actors issued the following commands to a SOGU implant at a victim:
These commands included setting persistence on the victim’s system.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: The actor then tested connectivity to an IP managed by the victim’s service provider.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: Once connectivity to the service provider IP was verified, the actor established the service provider IP as a proxy for the victim’s SOGU backdoor.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: This effectively routes SOGU malware traffic through the victim’s service provider, which likely indicates a foothold on the service provider’s network.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: The tactic also serves to mask malicious C2 and exfiltration traffic and make it appear innocuous.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: APT10 is a threat to organizations worldwide.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: Their abuse of access to service provider networks demonstrates that peripheral organizations continue to be of interest to a malicious actor – especially those seeking alternative angles of attack.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: We believe the pace of APT10 operations may slow following the public disclosure by the PwC/BAE blog; however, we believe they will return to their large-scale operations, potentially employing new tactics, techniques and procedures.
source: APT10 MenuPass Group _ New Tools & New Global Campaign.html

text: In 2018, the Cybereason Nocturnus team identified an advanced, persistent attack targeting global telecommunications providers carried out by a threat actor using tools and techniques commonly associated with Chinese-affiliated threat actors, such as APT10.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: This multi-wave attacks focused on obtaining data of specific, high-value targets and resulted in a complete takeover of the network.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Contact us to chat with a Cybereason Defender about Operation Soft Cell.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Earlier this year, Cybereason identified an advanced, persistent attack targeting telecommunications providers that has been underway for years, soon after deploying into the environment.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Cybereason spotted the attack and later supported the telecommunications provider through four more waves of the advanced persistent attack over the course of 6 months.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Based on the data available to us, Operation Soft Cell has been active since at least 2012, though some evidence suggests even earlier activity by the threat actor against telecommunications providers.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The attack was aiming to obtain CDR records of a large telecommunications provider.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The threat actor was attempting to steal all data stored in the active directory, compromising every single username and password in the organization, along with other personally identifiable information, billing data, call detail records, credentials, email servers, geo-location of users, and more.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text:
The tools and TTPs used are commonly associated with Chinese threat actors
During the persistent attack, the attackers worked in waves- abandoning one thread of attack when it was detected and stopped, only to return months later with new tools and techniques.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Add an additional security layer for web servers.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: For example, use WAF (Web Application FW) to prevent trivial attacks on Internet-facing web servers.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Expose as few systems or ports to the Internet as possible.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Make sure that all web servers and web services that are exposed are patched.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Use an EDR tool to give visibility and immediate response capabilities when high severity incidents are detected.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Proactively hunt in your environment for sensitive assets periodically.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text:
INITIAL COMPROMISE: THE MODIFIED CHINA CHOPPER WEB SHELL
MAINTAINING A LONG-TERM FOOTHOLD AND STEALING DATA
Watch our CEO Lior Div's keynote on the operation.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: In 2018, 30% of the telecommunications providers reported sensitive customer information was stolen due to an attack.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: These telecommunications providers have been expanding in size, to the point where In the past thirteen years, mobile cellular phone subscribers have quadrupled in size and sit at 8 billion subscribers today.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Due to their wide availability and the fundamental service they bring, telecommunications providers have become critical infrastructure for the majority of world powers.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text:
Watch the On-Demand Version of Our Operation Soft Cell Webinar
Much like telecommunication providers, many other critical infrastructure organizations provide a valuable targets for nation state threat actors, due to their high impact.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: In studies, nearly a quarter of critical infrastructure organizations reported they had been hit by nation state attacks and 60% said disruptive cyber attacks are among the threats they are most worried about.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Threat actors, especially those at the level of nation state, are seeking opportunities to attack these organizations, conducting elaborate, advanced operations to gain leverage, seize strategic assets, and collect information.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: When successful, these attacks often have huge implications.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Last year, we identified a threat actor that has been operating in telecommunications provider environments for at least two years.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: We performed a post-incident review of the attacks and were able to identify changes in the attack patterns along with new activity every quarter.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The threat actor mainly sought to obtain CDR data (call logs, cell tower locations, etc.)
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: belonging to specific individuals from various countries.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: This type of targeted cyber espionage is usually the work of nation state threat actors.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: We’ve concluded with a high level of certainty that the threat actor is affiliated with China and is likely state sponsored.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The tools and techniques used throughout these attacks are consistent with several Chinese threat actors, such as APT10, a threat actor believed to operate on behalf of the Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS).
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The threat actor changed activity every quarter.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The attack began with a web shell running on a vulnerable, publicly-facing server, from which the attackers gathered information about the network and propagated across the network.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The threat actor attempted to compromise critical assets, such as database servers, billing servers, and the active directory.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: As malicious activity was detected and remediated against, the threat actor stopped the attack.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The second wave of the attack hit several months later with similar infiltration attempts, along with a modified version of the web shell and reconnaissance activities.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: A game of cat and mouse between the threat actor and the defenders began, as they ceased and resumed their attack 2 more times in the span of a 4 month period.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The initial indicator of the attack was a malicious web shell that was detected on an IIS server, coming out of the w3wp.exe process.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: An investigation of the web shell, later classified as a modified version of the China Chopper web shell, uncovered several attack phases and TTPs.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The threat actor was able to leverage the web shell to run reconnaissance commands, steal credentials, and deploy other tools.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Malicious web shell activity as observed in the Cybereason solution.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Commands executed via a modified version of the China Chopper web shell.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: China Chopper is a web shell first discovered in 2012 that is commonly used by malicious Chinese actors.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: It is used to remotely control web servers, and has been used in many attacks against Australian web hosting providers.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The web shell parameters in this attack match to the China Chopper parameters, as described in FireEye’s analysis of China Chopper.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: This tool has been used by several Chinese-affiliated threat actors, such as APT 27 and APT 40.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: It is important to note that this tool is widely available and can be used by other threat actors.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The threat actor launched a series of reconnaissance commands to try to obtain and enumerate information about the compromised machine, network architecture, users, and active directory enumeration.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: One of the reconnaissance commands was to run a modified nbtscan tool ("NetBIOS nameserver scanner") to identify available NetBIOS name servers locally or over the network.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Nbtscan has been used by APT10 in Operation Cloud Hopper to search for services of interest across the IT estate and footprint endpoints of interest.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: It is also capable of identifying system information.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: NetBIOS Scanner execution as seen in the Cybereason solution.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: NetBIOS scanner is set to scan an internal IP range.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Following the reconnaissance phase, the threat actor attempted to dump credentials stored on the compromised machines.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The most common credential stealing tool used by the threat actor was a modified mimikatz that dumps NTLM hashes.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: This version of mimikatz did not require any command line arguments, most likely in an attempt to avoid detection based on command-line auditing.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The dumped hashes were used to authenticate to other machines via pass the hash.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: We renamed this sample to maybemimi.exe.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Modified Mimikatz that dumps NTLM hashes.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Reverse engineering shows the similarity between maybemimi.exe and mimikatz.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: In order to obtain credentials, the threat actor used another technique that can be seen in the below screenshots.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: They dumped specific hives from the Windows Registry, such as the SAM hive, which contains password hashes.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Reg.exe is being spawned from a shell process.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Command-line arguments indicate SAM hive dumping.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Once the threat actor mapped the network and obtained credentials (through net use), they began to move laterally.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: They were able to compromise critical assets including production servers and database servers, and they even managed to gain full control of the Domain Controller.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The threat actor relied on WMI and PsExec to move laterally and install their tools across multiple assets.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The following example demonstrates how the threat actor moved laterally from the first machine, compromised by the modified version of the China Chopper web shell, to other machines inside the network.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: /c cd /d
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text:
"C:\Program Files\Microsoft\Exchange Server\V15\FrontEnd\HttpProxy\ecp\auth\"&wmic /node:[REDACTED] /user:"[REDACTED]" /password:"[REDACTED]" process call create a.bat&echo [S]&cd&echo [E]
WMI command used by the threat actor to move laterally.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The threat actor abused the stolen credentials to create rogue, high-privileged domain user accounts which they then used to take malicious action.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: By creating these accounts, they ensured they would maintain access between different waves of the attack.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Once the threat actor regains their foothold, they already have access to a high-privileged domain user account.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: This significantly reduces the “noise” of having to use credential dumpers repeatedly, which helped them evade detection.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: A second method the threat actor used to maintain access across the compromised assets was through the deployment of the PoisonIvy RAT (PIVY).
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: This infamous RAT has been associated with many different Chinese threat actors, including APT10, APT1, and DragonOK.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: It is a powerful, multi-featured RAT that lets a threat actor take total control over a machine.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text:
Among its most notable features are:
File Manager with Upload and Download Support
Keylogging and Various other Surveillance Features
The control panel for PoisonIvy.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text:
Courtesy of Sam Bowne - samsclass.info
We assume the threat actor used PoisonIvy for keylogging and other surveillance features, as they had that functionality available to them as shown in the screenshot above.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The strain of PIVY in this attack used a DLL side-loading technique to stealthily load itself into memory.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: To accomplish this, it exploited a trusted and signed application.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text:
The PIVY payload was dropped along with the trusted and signed Samsung tool (RunHelp.exe) in the following manner:
Post-persistence execution of PIVY, side-loaded into a legitimate Samsung application.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: PIVY’s use of DLL side-loading to abuse Samsung tools is not new, and has been reported previously by Palo Alto.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: In 2016 it was used to attack pro-democratic activists in Hong Kong, most probably by Chinese threat actors.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: ⚠️ Note: Our team has reached out to and advised the targeted organizations on active containment actions.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: In later stages of the attack, the threat actor deployed two other custom-built web shells.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: From these web shells, they launched reconnaissance commands, stole data, and dropped additional tools including portqry.exe, renamed cmd.exe, winrar, and the notorious hTran.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Reconnaissance and lateral movement commands launched from the secondary web shell.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The threat actor exfiltrated stolen data using multiple different channels including web shells and hTran.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: In an attempt to hide the contents of the stolen data, the threat actor used winrar to compress and password-protect it.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The winrar binaries and compressed data were found mostly in the Recycle Bin folder, a TTP that was previously observed in APT10-related attacks, as well as others.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: This threat actor is known to stage the data in multi-part archives before exfiltration.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The threat actor used the following commands to compress the data.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Compressed stolen data exfiltrated via web shell.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The contents of the compressed data was crucial in understanding the threat actor’s motivation for the attack, as well as what type of information they were after.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: In order to exfiltrate data from a network segment not connected to the Internet, the threat actor deployed a modified version of hTran.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: This ‘connection bouncer’ tool lets the threat actor redirect ports and connections between different networks and obfuscate C2 server traffic.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: There have been numerous reports of hTran being used by different Chinese threat actors, including: APT3, APT27 and DragonOK.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: The threat actor made some modifications to the original source code of hTran.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Many strings, including the debug messages, were intentionally changed and obfuscated in an attempt to evade detection and thwart efforts to identify the malware by antivirus and researchers.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Since the original source code for hTran is publicly available, we were able to compare the debug output to the original source code to show that it has indeed been modified.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html

text: Identifying modifications in a disassembly of the modified hTran.
source: Operation Soft Cell_ A Worldwide Campaign Against Telecommunications Providers.html
